value.name: Spotify API Integration
observations: Client credentials grant type cannot access user-specific listening history
Required scopes for user data: user-read-recently-played, user-top-read, user-library-read, playlist-read-private
Current credentials: Client ID and Secret configured in .env file
Alternative approach needed: User authorization flow with OAuth redirect
Limitation discovered: 2025-11-20
API credentials stored in VITE_SPOTIFY_CLIENT_ID and VITE_SPOTIFY_CLIENT_SECRET

value.name: Claude Code Statusline
observations: Statusline configuration lives in ~/.claude/settings.json with type:'command' and a bash command
Does NOT support ANSI color codes - they cause the output to be rejected or hidden
Requires plain text output with no trailing newline (use printf instead of echo)
Successfully displays emojis and UTF-8 characters
Updates automatically when ~/.bashrc_status is sourced and function is called
Shows at bottom of Claude Code interface

value.name: Statusline Troubleshooting Nov 2025
observations: Problem: Claude Code statusline was blank/not displaying despite correct settings.json configuration
Root cause: Original update_status_line() function used echo -e with ANSI color codes (\033[35m, \033[36m, \033[0m) which Claude Code statusline renderer doesn't support
Diagnosis method: Used 'xxd' and 'cat -v' to examine hex output and reveal ANSI escape sequences (1b 5b bytes)
Solution: Created update_status_line_plain() function that uses printf instead of echo -e and removes all ANSI codes
Format settled on: 'â° 01:08 PM | â›…ï¸ +71Â°F | ðŸŽµ Nothing playing' with pipe separators
Weather uses wttr.in with 30-minute caching to /tmp/.weather_cache_$USER to avoid WSL network slowness
Music tracking uses playerctl metadata for currently playing song/artist

value.name: Claude Code Hooks
observations: Event-driven automation layer that executes shell scripts or LLM evaluations in response to specific events during development workflow
10 event types: PreToolUse, PostToolUse, PermissionRequest, UserPromptSubmit, Stop, SubagentStop, SessionStart, SessionEnd, PreCompact, Notification
Two execution modes: bash hooks (shell scripts with JSON stdin) and prompt hooks (LLM-driven using Claude Haiku)
Flow control priority: continue:false > decision:block > exit code 2 > other exit codes
Configuration stored in ~/.claude/settings.json (user), .claude/settings.json (project), or .claude/settings.local.json (local)
Hooks run with full user permissions - not sandboxed, can access all files
Default 60-second timeout per hook, configurable

value.name: Hook Architecture Pattern
observations: Hooks are the 'operating system layer' - enforce universal policies regardless of which tool (Skill, MCP, subagent) triggers them
Single point of policy enforcement - one hook protects all paths to a dangerous operation
Complementary to Skills/MCP/Projects, not redundant
Configuration snapshot captured at startup, mid-session changes require /hooks review
Multiple hooks for same event run in parallel

value.name: UV Single-File Script Pattern
observations: Isolates hook dependencies from project dependencies using UV inline script declarations
Dependencies declared inline with /// script comments
Makes hooks portable across projects
Example: #!/usr/bin/env -S uv run --script with dependencies array
From claude-code-hooks-mastery repo by disler

value.name: Bash vs Prompt Hooks Trade-offs
observations: Bash hooks: Fast (<1s), deterministic, free, works offline, 100% predictable
Prompt hooks: Slower (1-5s), probabilistic, ~$0.0001/call, requires API, context-aware
Use bash for security rules, validation, high-frequency events, offline scenarios
Use prompts for judgment calls like 'is work complete?', context-aware approvals, natural language rules
Hybrid pattern recommended: bash hook denies fast, prompt hook approves with intelligence

value.name: Hook Security Best Practices
observations: Defense in depth: Layer PreToolUse (block), PostToolUse (validate), Stop (verify)
Allowlists over denylists - specify what's allowed, not what's blocked
Quote all shell variables to prevent injection
Validate input - never trust JSON from stdin blindly
Block dangerous patterns: rm -rf /, chmod 777, path traversal (../), remote code execution (wget|sh)
Always review hook implementations before deployment - hooks run with full permissions

value.name: projects-dashboard Hook Opportunities
observations: Phase 1 Critical: Credential protection (PreToolUse on Write/Edit), Git safety (PreToolUse on Bash), MCP health check (SessionStart)
Phase 2 High Priority: Port validation (prevent conflicts in vite.config.ts), Build validation (type-check after edits)
Phase 3 Nice-to-have: Session archival, Documentation sync, Dependency deduplication
Start with logging-only mode, validate for false positives, then enable blocking
Target: Hook execution time <500ms for bash, <2s for prompt hooks

value.name: Provider Cascade Pattern
observations: Multi-vendor resilience pattern from hooks-mastery repo
Try multiple LLM providers in sequence: OpenAI > Anthropic > Ollama > fallback
Graceful degradation - always returns something, never crashes
Handles API outages without configuration
Used in Stop hooks for completion messages with TTS

value.name: SessionStart Context Loading
observations: Proactive context injection pattern - load git status, open issues, health checks at session start
Reduces repetitive 'what's the status?' questions from Claude
Saves tokens by front-loading relevant info
Example context: git branch/status/commits, GitHub issues, MCP server health, Docker service status, port availability
Can set $CLAUDE_ENV_FILE for persisting environment variables

value.name: 5x/10x Rule for Skills
observations: Only create a skill if: done 5+ times already AND will do 10+ more times in future
Proven need + ongoing value = skill creation threshold
Prevents premature optimization and over-engineering
Skills have maintenance cost, must justify with repeated use

value.name: Skills vs Tools Taxonomy
observations: Prompts: One-time requests, no persistence, manual activation
Projects: Ongoing context, passive, session-based
Skills: Repeated workflows, automatic semantic activation, cross-session persistence
Subagents: Independent complex tasks, manual launch, session-based
MCP: External data integration, on-demand, always available
Skills are application layer, Hooks are operating system layer

value.name: Progressive Disclosure Pattern
observations: Three-tier loading: metadata first, instructions if triggered, files on-demand
Pull model (Claude decides) vs push model (developer specifies)
Enables scaling to 50+ skills without context explosion
Metadata: name, description, triggers (~100 tokens)
Instructions: workflow steps, edge cases (<5k tokens)
Files: code, configs, examples (loaded only when needed)

value.name: Semantic Triggering
observations: Skills activate based on context understanding, NOT keyword matching
Claude decides activation based on: user intent + skill purpose + current context
Not deterministic - same phrase might trigger different skills based on context
Vague descriptions reduce activation accuracy
Strong descriptions include: capabilities, triggers, boundaries, limitations

value.name: Skill Creation Process
observations: 1. Name: lowercase-with-hyphens format
2. Description: specific capabilities + trigger conditions + context boundaries + limitations
3. Instructions: prerequisites check + step-by-step workflow + validation + common pitfalls
4. Testing: normal operations + edge cases + out-of-scope verification
Avoid generic names like 'helper' - be specific
Description quality directly impacts activation accuracy

value.name: mcp-server-setup Skill Opportunity
observations: Priority: High (â­â­â­)

value.name: chronicle
observations: Personal timeline and event storage system (formerly memory-shack)
SQLite-based storage at .swarm/chronicle.db
MCP server integration for timeline events and key-value storage
Perfect for quantified-life integration - high-frequency metrics, development logging, personal timeline
Lightweight storage for time-based queries without Graphiti's API costs
Use cases: Spotify plays, calendar events, work activities, productivity metrics
Port 3002 for HTTP API backend
Built with Node.js, TypeScript, React 19, TanStack Table

value.name: JIRA chronicle Integration
observations: Integrates JIRA activity logging into chronicle timeline for quantified-life
Uses JiraActivityService pattern matching SpotifyService and CalendarService
Implements manual sync button rather than real-time webhooks
Tracks work_ticket_completed, work_ticket_started, work_status_change event types
Stores ticket snapshots in chronicle KV for change detection
Chosen over Option 2 (jira-wrapper direct logging) and Option 3 (separate microservice)
JiraClient code copied to quantified-life for pragmatic implementation speed
MVP focuses on completed tickets only, phases add status tracking and auto-sync
Designed for solo developer scale (5-20 active tickets, 100-200 events/month)
Uses JQL filter: assignee = currentUser() AND resolved >= -30d

value.name: work_ticket Event Types
observations: Event type prefix: work_ticket_* to avoid collision with manual work_* types
work_ticket_completed: Ticket moved to Done/Resolved status
work_ticket_started: Ticket moved to In Progress
work_status_change: Any status transition with from_status and to_status
work_ticket_assigned: Newly assigned to user
Metadata always includes: ticket_key, summary, project, status, url
Optional metadata: priority, labels, assignee, resolution, components
Timestamp uses ticket.updated field for accurate temporal placement
Namespace: quantified (consistent with Spotify/Calendar events)

value.name: JiraActivityService
observations: Located at quantified-life/src/services/JiraActivityService.ts
Orchestrates JIRA data fetching and chronicle storage
Uses JiraClient for API calls and ChronicleService for storage
Implements syncCompletedTickets() for MVP functionality
Stores last sync timestamp in chronicle KV (jira_last_sync key)
Performs incremental sync by comparing current state vs snapshots
Batch stores events using chronicleService.storeBatch()
Returns count of synced tickets for UI feedback
Future methods: syncStatusChanges(), syncAssignments(), backfillHistory()

value.name: Service Integration Pattern
observations: Pattern used by SpotifyService, CalendarService, and JiraActivityService
External API client (JiraClient, SpotifyClient, etc.) handles authentication and requests
Activity service layer orchestrates sync and change detection
ChronicleService provides persistence layer
Manual sync button in UI with last synced timestamp
Credentials stored in localStorage (encrypted/obfuscated)
Graceful error handling with try-catch and user-facing messages
Background async storage with Promise.allSettled for non-blocking
React Query hooks wrap service calls for caching and state management

value.name: quantified-life OAuth Integration
observations: Complete automatic sync system for Spotify and Google Calendar data into Chronicle timeline
Located in projects/quantified-life/server/ with collectors, routes, and utilities
Uses OAuth2 Authorization Code flow with refresh token persistence in Chronicle KV memory
Implements incremental fetching: Spotify uses 'after' timestamp parameter, Calendar uses sync tokens
Smart caching prevents over-querying: 1-hour minimum between syncs, configurable
Manual 'Sync Now' button in React UI for immediate updates
Stores events as 'music_play' and 'calendar_event' types in Chronicle timeline
Built using Task agents for parallel development: Agent 1 (Calendar), Agent 2 (API), Agent 3 (UI)
Dependencies: spotify-web-api-node, googleapis, express, cors
Performance: Syncs recent Spotify plays in <2s, Calendar events in <3s

value.name: Spotify OAuth Collector
observations: File: projects/quantified-life/server/collectors/spotify.js
Implements incremental fetching using 'after' parameter with Unix timestamp in milliseconds
Uses spotify-web-api-node library for API interaction
Automatically refreshes access tokens using refresh tokens stored in Chronicle KV memory
Fetches recently played tracks with limit=50 per request
Transforms Spotify API response to Chronicle timeline events with metadata: track_id, artists, album, duration_ms, played_at
Stores last sync timestamp in Chronicle KV memory at key 'quantified:sync:spotify:last_sync'
Batch stores events in chunks of 10 for optimal performance
Handles authentication failures by returning auth status to trigger re-authorization flow

value.name: Google Calendar OAuth Collector
observations: File: projects/quantified-life/server/collectors/calendar.js
Implements incremental fetching using Google Calendar sync tokens for efficient delta queries
Uses googleapis library (google.calendar v3 API)
Automatically handles 410 Gone errors (invalid sync token) by triggering full resync
Stores sync tokens in Chronicle KV memory at key 'quantified:sync:calendar:sync_token'
Fetches events with maxResults=250 per request
Transforms Calendar API response to Chronicle events with metadata: event_id, summary, description, start/end times, attendees, location, recurrence rules
Only syncs events from primary calendar
Batch stores events in chunks of 10
Built by Task agent in parallel with other components

value.name: Environment Inheritance Pattern
observations: Monorepo-friendly approach for managing environment variables across multiple projects
Root .env contains shared credentials (Spotify, Google, JIRA) - gitignored
Project .env.defaults contains non-sensitive project-specific config (ports, endpoints, feature flags) - committed to git
Sync script (scripts/sync-env.sh) merges root .env + project .env.defaults â†’ project .env (auto-generated, gitignored)
NPM scripts: 'pnpm env:sync' (all projects), 'pnpm env:sync:quantified' (specific project)
Documented in docs/ENV_MANAGEMENT.md with usage, workflows, security best practices, troubleshooting
Prevents credential duplication across projects while allowing project-specific overrides
Safe for CI/CD: populate root .env from secrets, run sync script, build all projects
Updated .gitignore to ignore .env but allow .env.defaults with explicit negation patterns

value.name: Smart Caching Strategy
observations: File: projects/quantified-life/server/utils/smartCache.js
Prevents over-querying external APIs by enforcing minimum time between syncs
Default minimum interval: 1 hour (3600000ms), configurable per service
Checks last sync timestamp from Chronicle KV memory before allowing new sync
Returns detailed status: shouldSync (boolean), reason (string), nextSync timestamp
Reasons: 'Never synced before', 'Last synced X ago' (allows), 'Synced X ago' (blocks)
Used by sync API endpoint: POST /api/sync returns 429 Too Many Requests if cached
UI shows next available sync time when blocked
Balances freshness vs API rate limits and costs

value.name: Incremental Fetching Pattern
observations: Efficient API usage pattern that only fetches new/changed data since last sync
Two implementation approaches demonstrated: timestamp-based (Spotify) and sync token-based (Google Calendar)
Spotify approach: Pass 'after' parameter with Unix timestamp in milliseconds from last sync
Calendar approach: Pass 'syncToken' parameter from previous sync, handle 410 Gone for invalid tokens
Stores sync metadata in Chronicle KV memory for persistence across server restarts
Dramatically reduces data transfer and API costs compared to full syncs
Enables frequent syncs without hitting rate limits
Critical for scalability: full sync of 1 year of Spotify data = ~50 requests, incremental = 1 request

value.name: JIRA Fast Deduplication Script
observations: File: scripts/deduplicate-jira.js (formerly scripts/deduplicate-jira-fast.js)
Removes duplicate JIRA tickets from Chronicle timeline using parallel batch processing
Performance: 62x faster than sequential version (57.9s vs ~60 minutes)
Processes 50 deletions concurrently using Promise.allSettled()
100ms delay between batches to avoid overwhelming API
Successfully removed 1,623 duplicates from 3,980 events, achieving exactly 1,507 unique tickets
Deletion rate: ~1,681 events/minute (28 events/second)
Groups duplicates by ticket key, keeps earliest occurrence, deletes rest
Error handling: tracks failed deletions, continues on errors, reports at end
Result from production run: 1,623 deleted, 0 failed in 57.9 seconds

value.name: Parallelization Preference
observations: Always investigate parallelization options first for any task that can be parallelized
Opt for parallel execution over sequential when possible - it can provide 5-10x speedups
Use asyncio.Semaphore in Python or Promise.all in Node.js for controlled concurrency
Consider rate limits and resource constraints when setting concurrency levels
